Very old concept, modified to use more capable weapons. F-14s used cameras with long range optics to identify targets, and could engaged up to 6 enemy aircraft simultaneously while keeping their radars turned off so the enemy wouldn't even know they were around. Sadly the Phoenix missile, while great at long range engagement well out of the range of enemy missiles of the time, was not much good against lighter fighters due to limited maneuverability.

Sigh...  It's been done before and should of been easy to do for this fighter right off the bat.  Pheonix missiles used to be able to be pickled off 6 at a time to attack multiple targets at once under the right circumstances but due to the speed of the missile, 3-4 could usually be in the air at once.  That was with 1970's tech.  With the AAMRAM, they were able to fire 2-3 missiles (rated for 5 targets at once but the speed of missiles limited the number in the air due to repositioning because of limits to the angles of attack the lower generations of missiles had) at separate targets with the testing gear though it was never implemented in the early 2000's off of F-16's because the military considered it "wasteful" in their push for "assymmetrical"" warfare as large scale combat was deemed low risk.

The F-14 Tomcat equipped with the AUG9 system and Phoenix missiles could target 6 targets simultaneously back in the 1980's.   I'm not sure how the F-35 only being able to hit two simultaneously is such a milestone.

the Russians have a sharing radar system between ther MiG 25 and MIG 31 planes.  They fly 4 at a time and all their radars share information and so one plane can track multiple targets at once.  they have had this for years.

Seems like nothing to brag over 30 years ago, the F-14's AN/AWG-9 radar offers a variety of air-to-air modes including long-range continuous-wave radar velocity search, range-while-search at shorter ranges, and the first use of an airborne track-while-scan mode with the ability to track up to 24 airborne targets, display 18 of them on the cockpit displays, and launch against 6 of them at the same time. This function was originally designed to allow the Tomcat to shoot down formations of bombers at long range.  (per Wikipedia.)  This radar was designed to work AIM-54 Phoenix which had range or 125 miles and Mach 5 speed.

It is hard to know what to make of these stories as the plane performance details and full weapon system capabilities are likely classified, for good reason.  It does sound like the new software systems and sensors are more capable than previous US versions, but the key is staying ahead of potential adversaries.  That is hard for the American public to judge when the details are classified, as they should be.

In addition, no one fully knows a system's effectiveness from its capabilities and also its faults until the system is under the pressure of the demanding and unforgiving environment of combat.
